etymology.description: 酉(酉) (yǒu, "bottle") + 人(人) (rén, "person") + 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") -> person bending over a bottle to drink -> bronze script: 口 separate, become 今(今) (jīn), rest of body becomes 欠(欠) (qiàn) -> final: 食(食) (shí, "eat") + 欠(欠) (qiàn, "yawn") -> 飲(飲)
etymology.interpretation: The character illustrates the act of drinking as a person bent over a bottle. Over time, the depiction was stylized, repurposing 食(食) (shí, "eat") and 欠(欠) (qiàn, "yawn") to retain the original meaning phonetically and semantically.
etymology.simplification: In simplified Chinese, 食(食) (shí, "eat") is retained and 欠(欠) (qiàn, "yawn") remains, forming 饮. The character's form was likely adjusted for ease while maintaining pronunciation and meaning.

examples.chinese: 炎热的夏天(炎熱的夏天)，我常常饮上一杯冰水(我常常飲上一杯冰水)。
examples.pinyin: Yánrè de xiàtiān, wǒ chángcháng yǐn shàng yì bēi bīngshuǐ.
examples.english: In the hot summer, I often drink a glass of iced water.

examples.chinese: 他饮完了酒(他飲完了酒)，便上路了(便上路了)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǐn wán le jiǔ, biàn shànglù le.
examples.english: After he finished his drink, he set off.
